data.author: SamManbi
data.content: IN BRIEF: Sintana Energy to debut Tuesday on AIM after Challenger buy2025-12-18T14:17:44+0000 Sintana Energy Inc - Calgary, Alberta-registered oil explorer in Namibia and Uruguay - Sets date for its AIM listing after completing its acquisition of Challenger Energy Group PLC, which brought with it assets offshore Uruguay. Sintana, which already is listed in Canada and the US, will trade additionally on AIM, starting from Tuesday next week. It has appointed Zeus Capital Ltd as its nominated adviser and both Zeus and Cavendish Capital Markets Ltd as its brokers. Sintana has indirect interests in four petroleum exploration licences offshore Namibia, one onshore Namibia, and the two offshore Uruguay from Challenger. Sintana also has a pending interest onshore Angola, as well as legacy assets onshore Colombia and offshore The Bahamas. ‘Following the scheme becoming effective in relation to our transformational acquisition of Challenger Energy Group and our related commitment to provide local liquidity to AIM-based shareholders, we will have arrived at a key milestone,’ Sintana Chief Executive Officer Robert Bose says. Sintana says its market capitalisation on AIM is expected to be about £107 million. Its current market cap in Toronto is C$145.9 million, about £78.8 million. The company completed its £45 million all-share takeover of AIM-listed Challenger Energy earlier this month.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Sam - thanks for sharing your thoughts. I’m not surprised you’ve referred to Simon Potter and his extraction of value from the business. I’ve often wondered what the justification was! There were some that sung his praises prior to the failed Bahamas drill but when funds were extremely tight his remuneration package was a significant drain on resources. Perhaps he is an unsung hero behind the scenes! Any members of the Potter Appreciation Society stand up now! You’ve rightly referred to the “ de risking “ of Bahamas by the Columbus in quotation marks because there were a few who believed it, Starchild  being in the vanguard. In practice I believe it gave the company valuable time to reorganise under Koot’s smoke screen. He knew plenty more than he revealed at the early stages about Saffron viability ( or not!). Interestingly transferred his shares to his wife, possibly involving pension fund, from memory,but may be wrong on that detail. Subsequently shares were sold before big collapse. We’ll have to wait and see if the CEG/Sintana merger is out of same playbook. I’m wanting to believe it’s genuine because Total are making such a big commitment to PEL 83 and it’s got good history. Couldn’t open your link to Sintana commentators but most I’ve seen claim to have been too generous to CEG - if they were that desperate for our cash sounds like they might not have been generous enough - although the % was agreed on the specified date associated to then prevailing market caps. I’m still a newb on Sintana assets, but their website is interesting.As I said earlier today,  I’m expecting extensive PR from executives in the new year.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Sam - I’ll go further - it was a Dog’s Breakfast! I could speculate that it may have had a profound effect on Eytan and many investors that when  shyte or bust is risked and it turns out, pretty much, the latter much more attention needs to be given to risk management, going forward. The Chevron deal was, almost, out of this world but success is not guaranteed whereas PEL field is much more advanced and has proven up commercially so that the longer term interests of shareholders are being looked after. They’ll always be investors who don’t want to share risks and gains/losses and I can understand their disappointment but for many Sintana in its next phase will be exciting enough! Sam, historically, I’ve valued your beacon like support on here, when most of the posting was from the disgruntled FUD cohort. The fundamentals remain as strong now as when the merger was announced, I’d go so far as to say better, as the PEL development has been clarified and development targets published. Yes some wanted a quick cash sale and I’d speculate that’s scared off the TA watchers and some froth but fundamentals usually trump that in the long term. ATB!

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: From today’s RNS:- Suspension and cancellation of admission of Challenger Shares on AIM, listing of New Sintana Shares on the TSXV, and Sintana AIM admission A request has been made for the suspension of trading in the Challenger Shares on AIM with effect from 7:30 a.m. on 16 December 2025. Accordingly, 15 December 2025 will be the last day of dealings in, and for the registration of transfers of, Challenger Shares. Subject to the Scheme becoming Effective, it is expected that admission to trading of the Challenger Shares on AIM will be cancelled by no later than 8:00 a.m. on 17 December 2025. A further announcement will be made when the Scheme has become Effective. It is expected that Admission will become effective and dealings for normal settlement in the New Sintana Shares on the TSXV will commence at or shortly after 8:00 a.m. (Toronto time) on 23 December 2025. As part of the Acquisition, Sintana will apply for admission of the Sintana Shares (including the New Sintana Shares) to trading on AIM as soon as practicable after the Effective Date, and it is expected that admission will become effective and dealings for normal settlement in the Sintana Shares (including the New Sintana Shares) on AIM will commence on or around 23 December 2025.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Thanks Stewart - have cut n pasted a tit bit from Malcy - the next James Bond? “ My spies in the industry tell me that a number of these deals are imminent with rumours of Qatar Energy apparently farming-in to the Shell blocks and Chevron interested in other blocks having already shown their interest in the area. But apart from the official release from ANCAP above nothing has been confirmed publicly about them-yet… In addition, adding excitement to the play it looks like APA are already talking about drilling their well on OFF-6 as soon as the end of next year. It will come as no surprise to readers that such excitement is being generated, as Eni point out, the area that they have farmed-into  ‘falls within the unexplored part of the Atlantic margin with close geologic analogies with proven petroleum basins’. In conclusion I think that this announcement validates everything that Challenger has said in recent years and undoubtedly means that their position, as holder of two of the most desired blocks offshore Uruguay, is of significant dominance. Without blowing any smoke, it does show that for a small company as CEG was at the time, acquiring these blocks without any major industry players finding out, was a master stroke which has already benefited by the farm-out of 60% of area OFF-1 to Chevron. The process between CEG and Sintana Energy is still ongoing but I can say that having been a huge fan of both companies before, I am of the view that as a combined entity, the new vehicle will have massive potential and with a first rate management and portfolio will be a must-have investment in the sector.” What a legend- more of these links and you’ll even have BigSi converted!

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Below is a twitter post regarding PEL 83 and Custos ( Sintana hold 49% of the 10% stake) . This allayed my concerns with regard to carrying costs. So development is being accelerated by a Major, cash conserved - what’s not to like! Namibian Sun @namibiansun THE TIES THAT BIND: Knowledge Katti’s Custos Energy has confirmed that TotalEnergies will assume operatorship of Namibia’s petroleum exploration license (PEL) 83 from Galp and has acquire a 40% participating interest in the license. The agreement triggers an accelerated exploration and appraisal program, including a minimum of three wells over the next two years, with the first potential well targeted for 2026. PEL 83 is home to blocks 2813A and 2814B, situated in the Orange Basin off the coast of Namibia, currently operated by a subsidiary of Galp Energia, SGPS, S.A. The update outlines a major shift in operations, with TotalEnergies set to take over as the new operator of PEL 83. Under the new agreement, TotalEnergies will acquire a 40% participating interest in PEL 83 from Galp, who previously held an 80% stake. Galp will continue to maintain 40% ownership in the block. As part of the deal, TotalEnergies has committed to launching an exploration and appraisal campaign that includes at least three wells over the next two years, aimed at further de-risking the block and facilitating the development of an initial production hub. The first potential well is currently under evaluation, with drilling expected to begin in 2026. The agreement also includes a funding arrangement for Galp’s first development project in the Mopane field. As part of the deal, TotalEnergies will carry 50% of Galp’s investments in the project, which will be repaid from 50% of future cash flows from the project once commercial oil production begins. Custos Energy, which holds a 10% working interest in PEL 83, will continue to benefit from this carry under the joint operating agreement. Namcor, Namibia’s national oil company, also holds 10%. "As a proud Namibian partner with a 10% stake, Custos Energy is committed to working closely with TotalEnergies and Galp to achieve our shared objective of first oil, delivering transformative value for Namibia and all stakeholders," Katti said, on behalf of his company. He highlighted the importance of the agreement for the Namibian economy, noting that the development will help the government achieve its goals outlined in the National Development Plan 6 (NDP6). Custos Energy, founded by Katti over a decade ago, remains one of Namibia’s few local oil and gas exploration companies.

data.author: BlackBat17
data.content: With TotalEnergies taking the operator role and carrying part of the development cost (50% of Galp’s spend) under the deal, the financial burden and execution risk for the project is less on Galp — and indirectly lowers risk for non-operators Custos & Sintana. The involvement of a deep-water major with strong technical and execution capabilities increases likelihood Mopane/PEL 83 moves from exploration/appraisal into actual development. That raises the chances that Sintana’s ~4.9 % interest ends up monetisable. Because the project is now under a major and being carried, market perceptions of risk should decline. For Sintana this should result  a re-rating even without immediate production.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Many thanks to Ride DaIce on the other channel for supplying the link to the recent Auctis Advisors LLP report on Sintana - well worth reading in its entirety. Historically I found the section on OFF-3 particularly informative as it explores the fortunate stroke of serendipity that enabled Eytan to acquire that license. Don’t forget when Napoleon interviewed for Generals he always asked them if they had luck! Many people make their own luck - like Gary Player who was famously quoted “ the more i practice the luckier I get “ . Also note you have to be in it to win it! We heard so often from the trolls and disenchanted Eytan was only given it cos no one else wanted it ! LOL! Here’s the Auctis quote:- “ At the time of the licensing round, only companies already present in Uruguay were eligible to apply as no ‘ outsider ‘ had registered for the round in time.Apache was focused exclusively on ultra- deep water opportunities, whilst Shell - operator of the adjacent OFF- 2 and OFF-7 was constrained by regulations preventing any single company from holding more than 30,000 km2 of acreage. Applying for Area OFF-3 will have taken Shell beyond this limit at the time thereby disqualifying it from competing. With no effective competition, Challenger was the sole bidder. Uruguay, keen to have all offshore acreage licensed, awarded OFF-3 to Challenger at a very low entry cost , enabling it to secure a strategic position with minimal up front investment. “

data.author: SamManbi
data.content: IN BRIEF: Sintana Energy to debut Tuesday on AIM after Challenger buy2025-12-18T14:17:44+0000 Sintana Energy Inc - Calgary, Alberta-registered oil explorer in Namibia and Uruguay - Sets date for its AIM listing after completing its acquisition of Challenger Energy Group PLC, which brought with it assets offshore Uruguay. Sintana, which already is listed in Canada and the US, will trade additionally on AIM, starting from Tuesday next week. It has appointed Zeus Capital Ltd as its nominated adviser and both Zeus and Cavendish Capital Markets Ltd as its brokers. Sintana has indirect interests in four petroleum exploration licences offshore Namibia, one onshore Namibia, and the two offshore Uruguay from Challenger. Sintana also has a pending interest onshore Angola, as well as legacy assets onshore Colombia and offshore The Bahamas. ‘Following the scheme becoming effective in relation to our transformational acquisition of Challenger Energy Group and our related commitment to provide local liquidity to AIM-based shareholders, we will have arrived at a key milestone,’ Sintana Chief Executive Officer Robert Bose says. Sintana says its market capitalisation on AIM is expected to be about £107 million. Its current market cap in Toronto is C$145.9 million, about £78.8 million. The company completed its £45 million all-share takeover of AIM-listed Challenger Energy earlier this month.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Below is a twitter post regarding PEL 83 and Custos ( Sintana hold 49% of the 10% stake) . This allayed my concerns with regard to carrying costs. So development is being accelerated by a Major, cash conserved - what’s not to like! Namibian Sun @namibiansun THE TIES THAT BIND: Knowledge Katti’s Custos Energy has confirmed that TotalEnergies will assume operatorship of Namibia’s petroleum exploration license (PEL) 83 from Galp and has acquire a 40% participating interest in the license. The agreement triggers an accelerated exploration and appraisal program, including a minimum of three wells over the next two years, with the first potential well targeted for 2026. PEL 83 is home to blocks 2813A and 2814B, situated in the Orange Basin off the coast of Namibia, currently operated by a subsidiary of Galp Energia, SGPS, S.A. The update outlines a major shift in operations, with TotalEnergies set to take over as the new operator of PEL 83. Under the new agreement, TotalEnergies will acquire a 40% participating interest in PEL 83 from Galp, who previously held an 80% stake. Galp will continue to maintain 40% ownership in the block. As part of the deal, TotalEnergies has committed to launching an exploration and appraisal campaign that includes at least three wells over the next two years, aimed at further de-risking the block and facilitating the development of an initial production hub. The first potential well is currently under evaluation, with drilling expected to begin in 2026. The agreement also includes a funding arrangement for Galp’s first development project in the Mopane field. As part of the deal, TotalEnergies will carry 50% of Galp’s investments in the project, which will be repaid from 50% of future cash flows from the project once commercial oil production begins. Custos Energy, which holds a 10% working interest in PEL 83, will continue to benefit from this carry under the joint operating agreement. Namcor, Namibia’s national oil company, also holds 10%. "As a proud Namibian partner with a 10% stake, Custos Energy is committed to working closely with TotalEnergies and Galp to achieve our shared objective of first oil, delivering transformative value for Namibia and all stakeholders," Katti said, on behalf of his company. He highlighted the importance of the agreement for the Namibian economy, noting that the development will help the government achieve its goals outlined in the National Development Plan 6 (NDP6). Custos Energy, founded by Katti over a decade ago, remains one of Namibia’s few local oil and gas exploration companies.

data.author: BlackBat17
data.content: With TotalEnergies taking the operator role and carrying part of the development cost (50% of Galp’s spend) under the deal, the financial burden and execution risk for the project is less on Galp — and indirectly lowers risk for non-operators Custos & Sintana. The involvement of a deep-water major with strong technical and execution capabilities increases likelihood Mopane/PEL 83 moves from exploration/appraisal into actual development. That raises the chances that Sintana’s ~4.9 % interest ends up monetisable. Because the project is now under a major and being carried, market perceptions of risk should decline. For Sintana this should result  a re-rating even without immediate production.

data.author: in4cedros
data.content: Many thanks to Ride DaIce on the other channel for supplying the link to the recent Auctis Advisors LLP report on Sintana - well worth reading in its entirety. Historically I found the section on OFF-3 particularly informative as it explores the fortunate stroke of serendipity that enabled Eytan to acquire that license. Don’t forget when Napoleon interviewed for Generals he always asked them if they had luck! Many people make their own luck - like Gary Player who was famously quoted “ the more i practice the luckier I get “ . Also note you have to be in it to win it! We heard so often from the trolls and disenchanted Eytan was only given it cos no one else wanted it ! LOL! Here’s the Auctis quote:- “ At the time of the licensing round, only companies already present in Uruguay were eligible to apply as no ‘ outsider ‘ had registered for the round in time.Apache was focused exclusively on ultra- deep water opportunities, whilst Shell - operator of the adjacent OFF- 2 and OFF-7 was constrained by regulations preventing any single company from holding more than 30,000 km2 of acreage. Applying for Area OFF-3 will have taken Shell beyond this limit at the time thereby disqualifying it from competing. With no effective competition, Challenger was the sole bidder. Uruguay, keen to have all offshore acreage licensed, awarded OFF-3 to Challenger at a very low entry cost , enabling it to secure a strategic position with minimal up front investment. “

data.author: SamManbi
data.content: IN BRIEF: Sintana Energy to debut Tuesday on AIM after Challenger buy2025-12-18T14:17:44+0000 Sintana Energy Inc - Calgary, Alberta-registered oil explorer in Namibia and Uruguay - Sets date for its AIM listing after completing its acquisition of Challenger Energy Group PLC, which brought with it assets offshore Uruguay. Sintana, which already is listed in Canada and the US, will trade additionally on AIM, starting from Tuesday next week. It has appointed Zeus Capital Ltd as its nominated adviser and both Zeus and Cavendish Capital Markets Ltd as its brokers. Sintana has indirect interests in four petroleum exploration licences offshore Namibia, one onshore Namibia, and the two offshore Uruguay from Challenger. Sintana also has a pending interest onshore Angola, as well as legacy assets onshore Colombia and offshore The Bahamas. ‘Following the scheme becoming effective in relation to our transformational acquisition of Challenger Energy Group and our related commitment to provide local liquidity to AIM-based shareholders, we will have arrived at a key milestone,’ Sintana Chief Executive Officer Robert Bose says. Sintana says its market capitalisation on AIM is expected to be about £107 million. Its current market cap in Toronto is C$145.9 million, about £78.8 million. The company completed its £45 million all-share takeover of AIM-listed Challenger Energy earlier this month.

data.author: stewart3250
data.content: hi sam,  my original view was that it was a crap deal for ceg but i decided to stay perhaps influenced by malcy & robin mayes boards. i looked at the share price for sintana and its fallen from 124 to 61 and after the deal was announced its now 39.5, so both companies look crap. sintanas price is dragging ceg down but we are now part of them but the equivalent price is about 10p, makes you wonder what goes on, anyway we are where we are, somewhat ****ed off with ceg board agreeing to it when we had chevron with us.

data.author: SamManbi
data.content: The value of Challenger shares were shot 13p when did deal with announce. Now each share is worth roughly 9.7 p. The only positive thing here is that it's not as big of a Dog's Dinner as the P1 funding fiasco.
